text: IIUC someone in the Julia chat here was a Snakemake dev. Why do ypu find it so cool?

elements.text: IIUC someone in the Julia chat here was a Snakemake dev. Why do ypu find it so cool?

text: I use it daily for my work. Snakemake is very handy. But it also means I need to maintain my codebase in both Python and Julia

elements.text: I use it daily for my work. Snakemake is very handy. But it also means I need to maintain my codebase in both Python and Julia

text: And also, because Snakemake creates a new process for each job, and some of these jobs are <1 second long, Julia's startup time is really rough for performance. (I know, I know, PkgCompiler, but it makes quick iteration of the pipeline super annoying)

elements.text: And also, because Snakemake creates a new process for each job, and some of these jobs are <1 second long, Julia's startup time is really rough for performance. (I know, I know, PkgCompiler, but it makes quick iteration of the pipeline super annoying)

text: Oh. So is it like make and cmake but more batcheable?

elements.text: Oh. So is it like make and cmake but more batcheable?

text:
I never actually used `cmake` , so I don't have much of a reference point there. The file is basically a Python script, so you can mix Python code and the workflow logic together, which is really nice, e.g. you can do
```def some_function(x):
    ...

if some_function(my_data):
    # define some rules that define the workflow
else:
    # define other rules```
It's particularly useful in bioinformatics (the original author of Snakemake is a bioinformatician who know heads BioRust), because we tend to have long convoluted pipelines with many files. I often have > 1200 individual jobs in a workflow

cmake

It's particularly useful in bioinformatics (the original author of Snakemake is a bioinformatician who know heads BioRust), because we tend to have long convoluted pipelines with many files. I often have > 1200 individual jobs in a workflow

text: Ah, googling reveals make and cmake are about compilation. Nope, Snakemake is a tool for creating file-based workflows. Imagine you have a 15-step workflow you need to do on 100 files, with multiple steps that e.g. merges sets of files. Snakemake is like a "dependency resolver" of individual files, so you specify a set of rules for how scripts or shell commands create output files from input files, and then you specify the target output file, and then it resolves the chain of commands you need to execute and executes them in parallel

elements.text: Ah, googling reveals make and cmake are about compilation. Nope, Snakemake is a tool for creating file-based workflows. Imagine you have a 15-step workflow you need to do on 100 files, with multiple steps that e.g. merges sets of files. text: <https://github.com/caseykneale/MrPhelps> doubtful theres much of use in here...

elements.text: doubtful theres much of use in here...

text:
I think it's one of these things where it's moderately challenging to get something working, but then there are 100 edge cases that *will* show up once you begin using it
• What happens if you have jobs with an unknown number of outputs?
• What happens if the DAG needs to be updated depending on the result of some jobs?
• What if there are conflicts where some files could be produced by multiple rules?
• How do you distribute CPU cores if some jobs run an external programs that just consumes all your cores?
etc etc etc

elements.text: I think it's one of these things where it's moderately challenging to get something working, but then there are 100 edge cases that
will
show up once you begin using it
What happens if you have jobs with an unknown number of outputs?
What happens if the DAG needs to be updated depending on the result of some jobs?
What if there are conflicts where some files could be produced by multiple rules?
How do you distribute CPU cores if some jobs run an external programs that just consumes all your cores?
etc etc etc

text: Updating a dag isn't the end of the world, I mean if you dynamically insert a new procedure you have to lop off all previous work from that node onward.

elements.text: Updating a dag isn't the end of the world, I mean if you dynamically insert a new procedure you have to lop off all previous work from that node onward.

text: There shouldn't be ambiguity across multiple rule-sets. Basically you need to define whats associative and whats not. Or demand associativity - pretty common

elements.text: There shouldn't be ambiguity across multiple rule-sets. Basically you need to define whats associative and whats not. Or demand associativity - pretty common

text: managing CPU cores is a pain not gonna lie, but basically you have a compute dag and a resource manager. There are hundreds of graph theoretic optimization approaches to handle this problem. I imagine the simplest ones would be okay :D(IE a greedy approach).

elements.text: managing CPU cores is a pain not gonna lie, but basically you have a compute dag and a resource manager. There are hundreds of graph theoretic optimization approaches to handle this problem. I imagine the simplest ones would be okay :D(IE a greedy approach).

text: As for unknown outputs, wellll I intended to solve that stupidly. I was going to ask the user for either test files(to ensure nothing explodes at the last step) and/or run a result first. Monitor the resources used(important for optimal distribution of tasks anyways.
